business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Regrettably Senator Kemp is ill and will not be able to attend question time. He is suffering from food poisoning. In his absence Senator Ellison will take his questions.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Ellison. Can the minister confirm that the government has already sought expressions of interest from stockbrokers for the sale of the second tranche of Telstra, and that global coordinators for the second tranche sale are expecting to reap a windfall of up to $1.1 billion for the sale of the rest of Telstra, totally funded from the current Australian majority public ownership of this asset? How can the minister justify handing $1 billion to the finance industry when the social bonus, or return to the current shareholders, will amount to no more than $670 million?

—I can advise the Senate that total Telstra 2 sale costs are likely to be in the order of $200 million to $250 million based on expected proceeds implied by Telstra's current share value of around $10 billion to $15 billion. I daresay Senator Murphy has seen that article in the AFR which speculated on sale costs in relation to Telstra 2. That article fails to take into account the fact that the total sale costs include payments made in relation to the business adviser, the selling syndicate, legal and accounting advisers and other associated matters. As to the question of who the brokers are, I will get back to Senator Murphy.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, shouldn't the government be spending less time talking to stockbrokers and more time talking to the Auditor-General, given the failings he found in the first sale? How will the government ensure that the current shareholders are not again short-changed through unrealistic pricing, improper accountability for marketing costs and lack of foreign currency hedging? And given Minister Vanstone's conspicuous failure last week, will the minister assure the Senate that the Auditor-General's findings will be referred for a comprehensive investigation by appropriate law enforcement authorities before those stockbrokers are allowed to bid for work on the second tranche?

—The ANAO report which looked into this matter noted that the sale was done in accordance with the government's sale timetable in a period of significant equity market volatility. That report stated, `This sale represents a significant achievement given the unprecedented scale of the offer.' I reject Senator Murphy's premise that the ANAO is critical of this sale. In fact, it is not. The sale of Telstra was a successful one which paid rich dividends to ordinary Australians.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. Will the minister outline the economic and social benefits which will flow from the Jabiluka mine, in particular the benefits to local indigenous communities?

—I thank Senator Parer for his question and I congratulate him as my predecessor on the tremendous work he did in relation to the Jabiluka mine. In the welter of emotion in relation to the views of a few foreign bureaucrats about this particular mine, the real benefits for Australia and in particular the local Aboriginal communities have been ignored. These build on the tremendous benefits that have flowed from the neighbouring Ranger uranium mine, which has operated for 18 years without causing any environmental issues at all. The Ranger uranium mine has contributed some $48 million in benefits to traditional owners. In fact, the Jabiluka mine, which has not actually com menced operation, has already provided benefits to the local Aboriginal people of $3.7 million. Aboriginal communities are estimated to receive some $210 million in royalties from the Jabiluka mine.

answer.para: We see many crocodile tears being shed by the opposition parties over how we should be providing additional benefits to Aboriginal people and improving their standards of living. But when it comes to a project like this, which, as I say, is going to provide $210 million, where are the opposition? In addition to that, there will be employment and training opportunities for the local Aboriginal people, new housing for about 65 Aboriginal families, assistance for Aboriginal businesses, funding of a women's resource centre, a bridging education unit for local Aboriginal children and traineeships and university scholarships for Aboriginal students and for adult education.

In addition to those tremendous benefits for the local Aboriginal people, the mine itself is going to support about 350 jobs—we hear that the opposition is concerned about jobs; they say `No' whenever you want to put up a job creation proposal—and 1,500 indirect jobs. It is estimated that the project will deliver export revenue of some $12 billion to the Australian community. It is also worth reminding the Senate that the traditional owners gave consent to uranium mining at Jabiluka in 1982 under the land rights act and consented to the transfer of mining rights to ERA in 1991.

Under the supervision of Senator Hill, this mine has been through the most rigorous environmental impact assessment imaginable—probably the severest in the world. It should be noted that the mining lease for the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine has never been part of the Kakadu National Park and has never been part of the Kakadu world heritage area—something that is forgotten in the welter of emotion we hear from those opposite. The Australian editorialised on this matter just recently. It said:
To suggest that Jabiluka with an area of 20.5 hectares threatens the world heritage values of the park's 1.98 million hectares verges on the absurd.
I would also like to quote Jonathan Nadji, who wrote to Senator Hill on behalf of his family as traditional owners of land in the Kakadu National Park. He said:

I am concerned that without Jabiluka there will be limited economic opportunities for Aboriginal people in the region. I am concerned because my country is in this region, and I want my children to be educated here, to have employment opportunities within the region and to carry out their responsibilities to look after our country when I am too old. If there is no economic development, we will have to continue to rely on what the government considers is good enough to suit the needs of Aboriginal people who look after their traditional lands.

This mine has been through the strictest assessments possible. It will provide enormous benefits to Aboriginal people and to the Australian nation. The opposition ought to support it, not try and stop it.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware of the recent report commissioned by the Australian Research Council titled Information Technology: Sink or Swim ? If so, does the minister agree with the finding of that report that the amount of IT research currently being conducted in Australia is well below comparable countries, and that we are going backwards rapidly in IT research compared with our Asian neighbours? Does the minister accept that this situation is a direct consequence of the government's short-sighted decisions in its first two budgets to dramatically cut research and development assistance to industry? Furthermore, does he accept that a GST will simply add to the damage to an important service based industry which is crucial to Australia's future prosperity?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am sorry that Senator Lundy only comes to question time occasionally, otherwise she would have heard me spelling out chapter and verse the benefits of the GST to the IT industry. A 10 per cent GST will replace a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on everything from computers to modems to printers to playstations. In other words, the whole range of IT equipment and hardware is going to be dramatically cheaper as a result of the new tax reform that we are proposing to introduce.

answer.para: It is very sad indeed that Senator Lundy seems to demonstrate such an abysmal ignorance of what is driving this industry. There she was out there today saying that it was sad that the government had signed up to the US agenda on e-commerce. What are we talking about here? Who is the world leader? Talk about putting blind ideological prejudice ahead of an awareness of what is really happening out there! Senator Lundy thinks that there are a few cheap votes in pandering to the left wing of the Labor Party. Presumably the good old union that you come from thinks that is very good stuff. No doubt they stand up at branch meetings and say, `We want you to get out there and bag the US. We want you to get out there and say, "That's the devil." We don't like the idea of the US having anything to do with Australia in terms of trade.'

Face up to the facts. The facts are that the US dominates electronic commerce; it dominates the IT world. You have to have regard to what is going on in those places. The great bulk of research is being done in the US because it just happens to be a market of 260 million people compared with our population of about 18 million, so it is not altogether surprising that most of the R&D would be done there.

It is also driven very much by the military establishment, as you well know, and the spin-off effects from that research. What we are doing in this country is not affected by the changes to the R&D tax incentives because, as you well know, those changes were driven by the need to ensure that we had more equality of treatment. But we did also provide a number of taxation incentives through R&D Start—

talk.start.para: —Nonsense!
—You wouldn't know the difference!
—Nonsense!
—There are too many interjections. Senator Alston, address your remarks to the chair.
—You're selling out Australia.
—Why didn't you take that job as a cleaner with the ILO when it was offered to you?
—Senator Cook, there is an appropriate time to debate this.
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Will you draw the minister's attention to the fact that he is supposed to direct his answers to you and not to me?

—I have drawn his attention, but you were shouting at the time and probably did not hear it. I said that there is an appropriate time for you to debate it and the minister should direct his remarks to the chair.

—I certainly will, Madam President. But you cannot hide behind the chair, my friend, quite as easily as that. If you don't want to cop it, don't interject, and you will be quite safe. The fact is that we have taken a number of decisions—particularly the industry innovation program which provides a two to one subsidy for investment in this area, and the pooled development funds. There are a whole range of areas and ways in which R&D in this country is being encouraged. We want to ensure that seed capital is available.
—You seem to think that has nothing to do with you.

—You seem to think that the government has got to do all this. You want the government to get out there and identify the particular project, then you want the government to fund it. Then, presumably, when it falls over, you will say it had nothing to do with you. We are very encouraged by the fact that increasingly there are a number of companies which are prepared to put their money on the table. If you read about Intel the other day, they said, `We're not so keen on being remorselessly lobbied to put a fad plant in almost every place that moves.' I see that Hendy Cowan now wants it in Western Australia. They are more interested in having $100 million available for venture capital projects.

answer.para: So all of these things go to assisting R&D. It is not just a matter of government hand-outs. The sooner Senator Lundy takes off those ideological blinkers, understands that the US is where most of the action is, understands that Australia can have a place in the sun if it works closely with the major players, the sooner she will have a better idea of where we are going. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The minister's evasion of the question is a reflection on their neglect of R&D over the last 2½ years. Does the minister, then, disagree with the public comments of Mr Peter Upton, the Executive Director of the Australian Information Industry Association, who said the drop in tax deductibility for R&D has led to a noticeable dip in business investment, and the President of the Australian Computer Society, Mr Prins Ralston, who said if the GST affects spending on essential IT projects, Australia faces potentially disastrous consequences?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Do I agree with a hypothetical? He said `if'. He did not make the assertion that any such thing had happened, so what is the point of asking me a hypothetical? More importantly, you ought to look at what is happening in the real world. There is a whole range of reasons why there might be ups and downs in terms of investment. It depends very much upon the world view of a lot of these major companies, and if they had thought for a moment that Labor was going to get into office—as you thought you might sneak in a few months ago—they may well have held back on their investment decisions. They may well have been saying, `There's no point investing in this country anymore. If Labor is likely to get into government, we had better take all these investments offshore.' Understandably, you get a number of variations in their business plans, but at the end of the day they will continue to invest here because they know that we have all the necessary preconditions, we have addressed the economic fundamentals, and we have a very stable—
—Nonsense!
—It might not be for you, but it is for them. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Given the importance of health insurance to families, could the minister outline the impact that the passage of the government's health insurance rebate legislation will have on low income Australians? These families currently scrimp and save to maintain private health insurance—to maintain their choice of doctor, their access to health care, and their peace of mind.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris. She, like me, comes from a state where families are unemployed—
—Where there are no coalition members in the Reps.

—Obviously, the Labor Party does not care about them. They are prepared to shout like a rabble while I am talking about something that is of such importance to Australians. Elderly people, both pensioners and retirees, and families with children give up everything else they possibly can to hold on to their private health insurance. It is necessary, because of the claims that have been made by the opposition, to debunk the myth that only well-to-do people take out private health insurance. Anybody who is really representing their electorate would know, as I do, that people struggle massively to retain private health insurance. Something like 700,000 Australians with incomes of less than $20,000 a year are struggling to maintain their private health insurance. That is a fact; it is not political rhetoric. Many of them are pensioners and retirees, and many of them are families with children. They want the peace of mind that private health insurance gives them.

answer.para: The Australian Association of Independent Retirees have made their views on this matter very clear. They say that more than 800,000 people aged over 65 have private health insurance, and they are generally not wealthy at all. In fact, 847,000 over-65s have health insurance. They want it, they want to keep it, and they want the government to help them keep it affordable.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is an appropriate time to debate the issues, and that is after question time, not during it. Senators should cease interjecting.

—For pensioners or retiree couples, a $600 rebate on a $2,000 premium is important. Perhaps the Labor Party is still dealing with the elites of Australia as they were when they were the government. They have no contact with reality. People have to decide whether they are going to maintain their homes, whether they are going to replace the spouting, or whether they are going to pay for their health insurance. Perhaps Labor does not understand those things anymore. For some people there are catastrophic consequences if they drop out of private health insurance.

answer.para: Members of private health insurance funds are dropping out of health insurance by two to three percentage points a year. That is not good for the public health sector; it is not good for people who want to have an alternative. If the numbers fall to 20 per cent at the expiry of the current health care agreement, the rich will not be disadvantaged, but the poor and the needy will be. They are already standing in queues, side by side with an ex-Prime Minister, his wife and his four children, all of whom are entitled to take a place in the queue despite having the means to provide for their own health care. And they have stood in queues, and we know it. The trouble is that they got an advantage in the queues.

Let us recognise that two people in the Labor Party recognised the need. Back in the 1970s, when private health insurance and the health scheme were introduced, Bill Hayden recognised that to have a healthy public sector you had to have a strong private sector. We are now seeing that that is true. We are having problems with the public sector because of the reduction in the strength of the private sector. Graham Richardson, as health minister, recognised exactly the same thing. The only trouble was that he was succeeded by Carmen Lawrence, who took pride in not having private health insurance, and her Prime Minister did not have it either and gloried in the fact. What does that do for the poor and needy that some people in this chamber purport to represent? It cuts them out of decent, timely and efficient health care because the wealthy have taken their place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister further explain the importance of maintaining a vital private health insurance system?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for the opportunity to say more about this subject, because clearly a number of senators on the other side of this chamber are ideologically opposed to giving people a choice in health care. They do not understand the realities any more of looking after the long-term interests of the poor and the needy. Something like 200,000 people have been helped to maintain their health insurance by the existing health insurance rebate. These are people who would otherwise have dropped out and joined the queues in public hospitals. We want to build on this and help more people. Our commitment is to Medicare and the public system, but it is also to helping the public system by making sure that the private system does not expire from the lack of care that it got over all those years of Labor government. It is amazing how they are so upset about our assisting in the private health area and giving people a choice. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Government Contracts: Administrative Review Council Report

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer the minister to the government's statement, which was tabled in the Senate on 26 November, that it would respond to the call from the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee for an extension of the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman to cover contracted-out services when the Administrative Review Council had completed its inquiry into the same matter. Is the minister aware that the ARC handed its report to the Attorney-General last August? Is the minister further aware that the ARC recommended an extension of the Ombudsman's jurisdiction to cover action by a contractor under a government contract? When will the government stop inventing excuses and commit itself to action to ensure that there are adequate safeguards and scrutiny of government services and functions contracted out to the private sector?

—The Administrative Review Council's report is with the Attorney-General at the moment. There is no delay in that regard. In relation to the response to that report, perhaps Senator Schacht ought to address his questions to the Attorney-General. In relation to the question of outsourcing, we require agencies to be fully accountable for services that they are responsible for delivering, including those services that are provided through an outsourced arrangement. Through these contractual arrangements severe sanctions can apply if contractors breach accountability requirements such as privacy and service levels. The type and appropriateness of these measures will vary between contracts and the responsibility rests with the individual agency to determine what accountability measures are required in each contract. This approach is fully consistent with the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997. In relation to the specific response to the Administrative Review Council's report, I suggest that Senator Schacht take it up with the Attorney-General.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I appreciate that advice, but I have to say, Minister, that you are all part of the same government and one would have thought that the minister you represent and the Attorney-General have had three months to tick-tack on the same report. My supplementary question is as follows: does the minister agree that the government's response to the Senate committee's report was at the very least ill-informed and that, given the recommendations of the ARC, there is simply no excuse for delaying action on this matter any longer?

—I deny outright that there is any delay as outlined by Senator Schacht. The ARC report is one which is currently with the Attorney-General and being looked at. That will be considered by the Attorney-General and then in an overall government context. That is where the matter lies.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. I refer the minister to the promotional video from Pangea Resources which states that Australia is the best country to store much of the world's high level nuclear waste, and the company's assertions that they have met with Australian ministers and officials about their plans for a nuclear waste dump in Australia. I ask the minister just two things. Firstly, does he agree with this claim that Australia is the best place to store high level nuclear waste? Secondly, will the minister rule out completely the importation and storage of nuclear waste? In other words, will he rule out completely any involvement of his government in setting up an international nuclear waste depository in Australia?

—I thank Senator Lees for the question. I must say that until this morning I had not heard of Pangea and I certainly have not seen the video, but I notice that the ABC is in a welter over this issue. My advice is that it was in fact our predecessors, the Labor government, that decided that we should find a suitable site in Australia for a national radioactive waste depository. That was announced by none other than Simon Crean as the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy back in 1992.
—Low level waste, and you agreed to it.

—That was in order to allow for the disposal of Australia's low level and short-lived intermediate level waste, and we agreed with that. Coming into government, we support the previous Labor government's proposition.
—This is about high level waste.
—Senator Schacht, cease interjecting.
—I'm just giving him a hand.

—Thanks, Senator Schacht, but I'll be fine. A preferred site for the depository will be recommended to the government we hope by the middle of next year. As I am sure Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus would agree, we hope that that will be in South Australia, because that would be good for our state. Can I say that no high level radioactive waste facility is planned for Australia and the government has absolutely no intention of accepting the radioactive waste of other countries. The policy is clear and absolute and will not be changed. We will not be accepting radioactive waste from other countries, and this repository is not for high level radioactive waste.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister prepared to seek advice from Pangea Resources as to whom it was that they did spend time with in Australia, and in particular to pass on to that company Australia's displeasure at being marketed internationally as a good place to store high level radioactive waste?

—In relation to the press reports this morning, I can confirm that as far as this government is concerned there have been absolutely no ministerial level discussions with that company, Pangea Resources. I am advised that representatives of Pangea have had discussions with government officials over the years—I think going back before we came into government—on the general issue of radioactive waste management, but those discussions have always been clearly on the premise that it is not government policy and will not be government policy to accept radioactive waste from other countries nor to accept high level radioactive waste.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister confirm that the government is reconsidering its decision not to introduce a privacy regime for the private sector? Isn't it true that the government has been embarrassed into this position by the decision of the Victorian government to introduce its own privacy regime? When will the government complete its backflip and give the Australian people the privacy protection they deserve?

—I thank Senator Denman for the question. The Attorney advises me that he does not propose to respond to speculation that has been circulating in the media about the government's approach to privacy protection. The facts are that the government has been and remains committed to ensuring good standards. I am sure Senator Denman agrees with that. We have a disagreement about how to do it but not a disagreement that it needs to be done. We want to ensure good standards of personal data protection across both the public and private sectors.

answer.para: The government's election policy platform committed it to reviewing the implementation of the self-regulatory privacy protection to ensure that businesses are protecting and properly handling personal information. The government is very pleased that some industry sectors have moved to adopt the Privacy Commissioner's national principles for the fair handling of personal information, which were issued in February this year after extensive consultation and as a benchmark set of privacy standards for the private sector.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my left, I would remind you there is an appropriate time to debate issues, and shouting constantly during an answer to a question is in breach of the standing orders.

—Thank you, Madam President. In line with that election promise, the government is reviewing the initiatives so far taken by industry to adopt privacy standards and how best to support self-regulation in the light of those initiatives. We are committed to ensuring that the development of any privacy scheme does not unreasonably increase the regulatory burden on business, particularly on small business.
—What are the sanctions if they breach it? There is no public accountability.

—Madam President, thank you for your support. Perhaps we need a scream room here so Senator Lundy can go and get it all out of her lungs instead of trying to interrupt everybody when they are giving an answer.
—Senator Vanstone, your remarks should not be directed across the chamber.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you prepared to tell us where you stand on this issue? Do you support the introduction of a legislated privacy regime for the private sector?
—Thank you, Senator Denman. I am sorry you wasted a supplementary question. You would well understand that I would, of course, support the Attorney and the government's position in this matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to media reports today about an industry proposal to establish an international nuclear waste storage facility in South Australia or Western Australia. Is it the case that the government is under international pressure to establish a facility of this type in Australia so that we can have a greater influence and involvement in the debate on nuclear issues? Is it also the case that such a move would also improve our prospects for the sale of Australian uranium?
—Madam President, I am not sure whether Senator Margetts excused herself from the chamber for a minute or two, but a question on that subject has been asked of Senator Minchin and well answered.

—Madam President, obviously the minister was not listening to the question. I will have to ask it again as a supplementary question. Isn't it the case that the government is under international pressure to establish a facility and that the argument is that we can have a greater influence and involvement in the debate on nuclear issues, including the non-proliferation treaty? I was asking him in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I just wonder what advice the minister has got from the foreign affairs department as to the implications for Australia in this instance.

—I am sure the Minister for Foreign Affairs would say that the government is under no pressure; furthermore, it is not intending to build a facility for the disposal of high-level nuclear waste. The question in relation to low level and intermediate level short-lived waste has been answered by Senator Minchin.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence: Funding

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Is it true that the cuts the government has made to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence have resulted in the bureau advising the minister that it may be forced to pull out of joint operations involving the Olympics, paedophile networks and the National Crime Authority? In particular, can the minister confirm that the ABCI has warned her that, because of its `current financial dilemma', it may have to choose between maintaining its criminal intelligence database and `focusing solely' on the `analytical side' of its operations, which includes Olympic security?

—I thank Senator Collins for the question. It is nice to see she is reading the papers of yesterday and has caught up with them by today. I read that article yesterday. Senator Collins may not understand, since she clearly does not have a close interest in these matters and gets her titbits of information out of the newspapers, that the ABCI is, in fact, funded partially by the Commonwealth and partially by the states. The ABCI has raised its concern that it does not, in its view, have as much money as it would like. I think that has probably been the case under previous governments as well. That matter, as I am advised, has been handled at officer level.
—You don't care—ministers aren't involved in this?
—The Senior Officers Group of the Australian Police Ministers Council discussed this matter recently.
—Why don't you care about this?
—Thank you, Senator Bolkus, for your constant interjections. It's about the most useful contribution you ever make in this place.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You just sit there and chatter away, indicating to the world what a useless creature you are. Chatter, chatter, chatter! You're like a canary in a cage.
—Senator Bolkus, stop interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. I am sorry to be distracted by that mindless chattering opposite. Senator Collins, back to your question: it is being looked at by the Senior Officers Group of the Australian Police Ministers Council.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. When did the ABCI first write to the minister setting out its concerns about the `financial crisis' that it is facing? Why hasn't the minister, rather than the Senior Officers Group, responded to its letter seeking additional financial support, given the very important issues I highlighted in my first question that are at stake?

—Thank you, Senator Collins. I do not have the specific date of the letter with me but I will get that for you. But don't underestimate the value of the Senior Officers Group of the Australian Police Ministers Council. It does very valuable work. It allows a significant amount of work to go on between APMC meetings—something you may get to understand if you ever get back into government.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. In light of recent calls for legalisation of heroin, would the minister please advise the Senate what the government's response is to the results of the Swiss referendum on legalisation of heroin?
—Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.
—I thank Senator Payne for her question.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht, you have been interjecting persistently.

—If there is one thing to be learned from international experience it is that there are no quick fixes on the question of drug abuse. The three to one vote in the Swiss referendum on the legislation of narcotics demonstrates that Swiss voters see that legalising drugs alone is not the answer. The fight against drugs must involve a partnership between supply reduction strategies, demand reduction strategies and harm minimisation strategies, just as the government's Tough on Drugs program does. Demand reduction strategies are far less likely to be effective where there are no supply reduction strategies in place at the same time.

answer.para: Under the national illicit drugs strategy, this government has committed over $200 million to a very balanced approach to the drug problem. Our approach attacks the drug problem on three fronts. Firstly, the government's Tough on Drugs strategy includes funding for a range of treatment programs. Secondly, we are also committed to anti-drug education and community awareness programs and, finally, we are taking action to stop the importation of illegal drugs—and, if I may say, being far more successful than the previous government ever was.

The new shadow minister for justice and customs seems to have a complete lack of understanding about what the government is doing because he calls for harm minimisation and education strategies when that is exactly what this government is implementing. He says, `First we need effective measures to be put in place to help reduce the amount of drugs coming into Australia.' That is our supply reduction measure. I do not know that Senator Gibbs or Senator Stott Despoja agree with that but, nonetheless, the shadow minister does. Secondly, he says we have to reduce demand by educating Australians. That is part of the Tough on Drugs strategy, too. Thirdly, he says, `We have to accept the reality that illicit drugs are out there and we need harm minimisation programs'—exactly what this government is providing. I am at a loss sometimes to understand exactly what non-government senators do think.

Senator Gibbs, however, appears to think we are putting too much effort into the fight against drugs, as does Senator Stott Despoja. So I give Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Gibbs the opportunity to nominate those law enforcement issues that they do not want us to proceed with. What law enforcement money do you want cut? Where else would you put that money?

talk.start.para: —Senator, your remarks should be directed through the chair, not across the table.

—Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Gibbs say the emphasis is too much on law enforcement; they want the emphasis to go to the other parts of the program. So it is incumbent on them to put their money where their mouth is and tell Australians what law enforcement programs they would cut. That is what we want to know—what would you cut? Equally, we have to understand that we cannot afford to treat people after they have been caught in the cycle. We need to try to stop some people getting on drugs and we do that by education programs and by limiting supply.

answer.para: A balanced approach has to do something about drugs coming into the country. It is naive to think that we can help Australia's young people without also fighting the drug criminals who profit very substantially from the sale of illegal drugs to young Australians. That is why we have given so much more to the Australian Federal Police recently. In November 1997 we gave them an additional $20 million for mobile strike teams, for witness protection and for the National Heroin Signature Program. talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In terms of demand reduction, supply reduction and harm minimisation, is there any further information you can offer the Senate on these issues?

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left should not be shouting.

—Senators on my right will cease talking across the chamber.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Boswell's figures are pretty accurate. answer.para: I have on other occasions made it clear that I do not believe that the arbitration process worked as effectively as it was intended to. —My question without notice is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Coonan for the question and for her interest in this very vital matter. A key initiative of the government's tax package was the introduction of a 30 per cent tax rebate for people who take out private health insurance. This initiative will strengthen the Australian health care system by encouraging people to take up or keep their private health insurance by putting, on average, $750 into each of their pockets. It will also take pressure off the public health system. Maintaining a strong balance between the public and private health sectors is vital for a robust health system for all Australians.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left are in breach of the standing orders.

—The opposition knows this, but they continue to oppose the initiative because of their ideological stubbornness. Former Labor health minister, Graham Richardson, knew this when he was minister, and he is still saying it today. They mock on the other side, but last week Graham Richardson said that the Labor Party's opposition to the 30 per cent health insurance rebate was `ridiculous'. This is what he said:

answer.para: They—
the Labor Party—
simply don't want to acknowledge that private health care matters. There is an ideological bent here that says Medicare is perfect . . . and therefore nothing should be done to private health . . .
This is the same man who in 1990 said:
If you allow the critical mass of about 40 per cent of people in private health insurance to be lost, then you run the risk of a threat to the entire system.

He said that as health minister, he said it again today, yet it is being ignored by the other side. Labor's intractability will result in serious consequences for the public health system. Firstly, the Commonwealth budget would be cut by $2.5 billion over the life of the existing health care agreement to compensate the states for every one per cent of people who dropped out of private health insurance. Secondly, under present trends 1.9 million Australians would leave the private system. This would mean an estimated 1.2 million extra bed days—that is, 3,300 extra hospital beds would be required in five years. That is the equivalent of building five to six extra public hospitals. Those figures are incontrovertible. They have not been responded to either by the Democrats or by the Labor Party.

The government has slowed the massive decline in private health insurance which it inherited from Labor. We are giving people what they want. It is about fairness and freedom of choice. The government has shown its commitment to a better health care system for all Australians. It is now up to the Senate to pass the legislation and make a difference.

Madam President, I heard some laughter the other day when I think Senator Crowley was saying that the Labor Party never intended that there should be a viable private system. I have a long memory. I was present at a meeting 25 years ago, and I quote from the then Minister for Social Security, Mr Bill Hayden, on 2 May 1973 when he said about the introduction of Medicare:
In this range of issues, there is absolutely no change at all. We have always postulated our schemes—

talk.start.para: —What did Disraeli say?
—Senator Robert Ray should listen; he was probably not around then. The quote continues:

answer.para: We have always postulated our schemes based on private medical practice, on private medical practice based on fee for service and in turn it will always be guaranteed, the freedom of choice between doctor and patient, the patient can choose his doctor and the doctor could make the decision whether he could bear the workload or not.

That is conveniently ignored. We are maintaining Medicare, basing it on freedom of choice for all Australians, no matter what their level of cover. We believe that Australians want freedom of choice—choice of doctor and choice of hospital, whether it be public or private. We intend maintaining that. The people with ideological blinkers on have turned around the other way. They do not recognise the basis of Medicare—and that is from the originator, the man who brought it in.

Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Gibbs. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
SENATOR GIBBS asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care on 30 November 1998

(1) Can the Minister confirm that the Government, and the Minister for Trade in particular, have been lobbying the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council to water down its proposal for mandatory labelling of genetically modified foods?
(2) Does the minister recognise that consumers are entitled to information on which they can base decisions about their food choices
(3) Will the Minister undertake to inform the Senate of the position the Government will be taking on this issue at the December meeting of the Australia new Zealand Food Council
SENATOR HERRON—The Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) No, the Minister for Trade wrote to all members of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council (ANZFSC) on 12 November 1998 supporting the decision of the Council at its 30 July meeting to adopt the recommendation of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) to require labelling of genetically modified foods where these are not substantially equivalent to their conventional counterparts in his letter the Minister for Trade also addressed the implications of the Council imposing mandatory labelling for substantially equivalent foods, beyond that recommended by ANZFA. In this regard the Minister drew Council members' attention to the potential undesirable impacts such a requirement could have on Australia's international competitiveness in the processed foods sector and obligations as a member of the World Trade Organization.

The Minister for Trade also supported the need for consumers to be provided with useful infor mation on which they can base their decisions relating to food choices but suggested that alternatives to mandatory labelling exist which would be consistent with Australia's international obligations and avoid unnecessary adverse impacts on industry

(2) The Minister fully recognises that consumers require accurate information on which to base their decisions about food. Where such information may be considered necessary to protect public health and safety, the use of mandatory labelling is appropriate. As the ANZFSC decision of 30 July 1998 also imposed pre-market safety testing for all genetically modified foods, there is no safety issue in this case. It is important to recognises that there are many ways in which consumers are currently provided with information without a mandatory labelling requirement. Furthermore there is sufficient doubt as to whether a simplistic statement of the type implied by a mandatory labelling requirement would achieve the objective of providing useful information to consumers.

In view of the costs to industry of such a requirement, which would inevitably be passed onto consumers, it is appropriate to examine alternative ways of meeting consumer expectations for information about gene technology which are supportive of the development of Australia's food industries and consistent with our international obligations, before imposing a mandatory requirement.

(3) At its meeting, on 30 July 1998, ANZFSC requested ANZFA to provide an additional briefing on developments internationally and within the major trading blocs concerning the labelling of genetically modified foods. The briefing will be provided to ANZFSC at its meeting scheduled for 17 December 1998 at which members, including the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, will discuss the labelling of substantially equivalent foods and reach a conclusion about whether further measures are required.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, I was asked a question by Senator Brown in relation to civil protest in Irian Jaya. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator Brown asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on 30 November 1998

1. Is the Government monitoring the situation whereby last Thursday, two naval ships dropped members of the special mobile police force from the Indonesian police, the army's second level special forces, navy special forces and 16 trucks at Manokwari?
2. Are the Indonesian authorities confiscating the Morning Star flag as well as farm implements?
3. Is a massacre possible tomorrow with the raising of this flag?
4. Will the Australian Government urgently contact the Indonesian authorities to avert tomorrow any repeat of the Biak massacre?
Supplementary question:

5. Will the Minister investigate the matter and urgently contact the Indonesian Government to try to ward off the potential for a further massacre in our nearest neighbour, West Papua, specifically in Manokwari tomorrow when this flag-raising ceremony occurs?
Senator Hill—The answer to the Senator's question is as follows:

1. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has received reports of troop build-ups in a number of towns in Irian Jaya, including Manokwari. This activity is apparently in anticipation of separatist demonstrations marking the 1 December anniversary of the 1961 declaration of independence in Irian Jaya.
2. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has not been able to confirm whether the authorities have confiscated Morning Star flags or farming implements.

3. Civil disturbances are a possibility in such a scenario, but the local authorities appear to be working to avoid violent confrontations The Embassy's contacts have reported that the local government and military have urged people not to demonstrate on 1 December, and have approached ex-Organisasi Papua Merdeka (OPM) and church leaders to discourage demonstrations. A Jayapura newspaper reported on 28 November that an Irianese leader had postponed his plans to hold demonstrations on 1 December, calling instead for a day of prayer. This decision was reportedly welcomed by the Governor of Irian Jaya. In the interest of avoiding violence, the Australian Government urges all sides to exercise such restraint.

4. On 30 November the Australian Embassy in Jakarta conveyed its concerns to ABRI about the possibility of an over-reaction by authorities to separatist demonstrations in Irian Jaya. The Embassy emphasised the importance of avoiding a situation similar to that which took place in Biak in July this year. The Embassy's ABRI contacts advised that they would contact military authorities in Jayapura regarding this issue.

5. The Government has already made its concerns about the possibility of civil disturbances in Irian Jaya known to the Indonesian authorities. The Government has no information to indicate that the situation in Manokwari should be of greater concern than anywhere else in Irian Jaya.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferris today, relating to the Government's proposed private health insurance rebate.

Today, we have seen poor taste plummet to greater depths in Senator Newman's answer to the question that Senator Ferris asked her in question time. This was a prepared dorothy dixer answer to a question which she had ample knowledge of. Obviously for Senator Newman, in order to make some sort of cheap political point about the purported benefits of the government's $1.4 billion give away to taxpayers who have private health insurance, Senator Newman felt obliged to drag into her answer the former Prime Minister Mr Keating and his family. What an inappropriate day for her to do so. It was disgusting and tasteless on Senator Newman's part. It is typical of the modern Liberal Party and very typical of Senator Newman. It says more about Senator Newman's lack of judgment than it says about anything else.

We have seen yet again from Senator Newman in this chamber today that the Howard government is all at sea on the question of funding of the health system in this country. In the past 24 hours we have had the spectacle of the government trying to defend its position that the Australian taxpayer should be subsidising tennis racquets, gym memberships and hydrotherapy for yuppies. The Howard government has attempted to bribe the holders of private health insurance by rebating them 30 per cent of the cost of their ancillary cover for sports goods and membership.

You have to ask yourself: how has this issue been received by the Australian public? We have seen a very interesting reaction in the newspaper this morning and on talkback radio. In fact, yet again in the chamber today not only have we had Senator Newman in answer to the question from Senator Ferris but also, in answer to a dorothy dixer, Senator Herron quoted the former health minister Graham Richardson. I got a transcript of what Graham Richardson actually said this morning. To put the record straight, let me quote it into Hansard so that we can have a debate about what he really said, instead of the words put into his mouth by Senator Herron and by Senator Newman. This is a direct quote from Graham Richardson this morning on Sydney Radio 2GB:

I've been telling you that the 30 per cent health insurance rebate is stupid policy. But the thing that's more stupid than even I thought, apparently $300 million of our money will go on all sorts of things we never realised, such as: $139 million for subsidised dental care for people with private health . . . . teeth, it gets even worse. Apparently we're also going to be paying out for them to have hypnotherapy, natural therapies, and even optical care. More importantly, we're to pay out nearly $9 million for fitness and lifestyle courses and equipment—gym equipment. That's what was paid out in the last financial year. I just can't believe that they're doing all of this and why are they doing it? It was explained . . . by the Government by Dr Wooldridge as a philosophical statement.

Let us be clear that the Howard government is pushing ahead with a massive transfer of public resources from the public health system directly into the private health system. Dental health care is a terrific example of this resources transfer. The government slashed public dental health funding in its first budget and it is now proposing to directly subsidise the dental treatment of the elites in this country to the tune of 30 per cent of the $600 million spent on dental care each year. This is the way in which this government has operated. We say that money should be put into the public health system immediately, before it dies the lingering death which this government wants to see. The elites of Australia are the big winners under this government's policy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is quite easy to understand why the Labor Party is so embarrassed about having locked themselves into the position of opposing an initiative which received the overwhelming support of the Australian people at the last election and which the Australian people are very supportive of in general.

speech.para: Senator Newman quite correctly pointed out in her answer that over 700,000 Australians who have private health insurance have an income of less than $20,000 per annum—hardly the rich and the glitterati that Senator Faulkner seeks to portray as the people who have private health insurance. Indeed, these are your average Australians who are very concerned to ensure that they have a choice in health care.

If we do not assist them, what is going to happen? All these people will be flung into the public hospital system and the system at the moment cannot cope. The lines are far too long already. The waiting lists are there. Everybody knows the difficulties that public hospitals right around this nation are facing. The Labor Party, because of their ideological bent—in fact, I would call it an ideological warp—cannot see their way clear to assisting the public health system by getting more and more people who can afford it, or who want it, back into the private health system.

Coming from the state of Tasmania, Madam Deputy President, I can tell you that the people of Tasmania have the highest rate of private health insurance in this country, combined with the lowest average income in the nation, the worst health outcomes in the nation and the most aged population in the nation. All of those factors combined should surely mean that at least the Labor senators from Tasmania would support this government initiative, because their failure to do so would be a betrayal of the people of Tasmania, just as the federal member for Bass betrayed the 26,000 people in her electorate who have private health insurance. And take the tip: the people of Bass will be reminded of the betrayal by the member for Bass of those 26,000 people come the next election.

Senator Faulkner feigns a degree of sensitivity in relation to the Keating family. The announcement that was made today was most unfortunate and I do not want to canvass it. Suffice to say that Senator Faulkner's harassment of the Baillieu family, members of whom were dead, for whom we have still not received an apology—

talk.start.para: —How long ago was that?
—For many years, Senator Coonan. Senator Faulkner came into this chamber having sought to vilify, incorrectly, the Crane family, without apology—
—And the Panizza family.

—And the Panizza family, that is quite correct. So it is hardly appropriate for Senator Faulkner to pretend that he has some degree of sensitivity to families that are involved in, or indeed are out of, politics. He was more than happy to drag the Baillieu family, the Crane family and the Panizza family through the public arena. Today, all of a sudden, he says, `Oh, but you can't do it to people associated with the Labor Party.' If it is good enough for Senator Faulkner to vilify people on our side of politics, I think it is appropriate for Senator Newman, not to vilify, but simply to refer to the facts that are on the public record in relation to Mr Keating, who said that he did not want private health insurance.

speech.para: But take the tip: if Mr Keating ever lined up for medical attention in a public hospital, do you think he would have to wait for hours and hours on end with all the other people or do you think he might be able to manipulate his way through and get served virtually immediately? We know how the system works and that is why people who are able to afford private health insurance ought to have health insurance and, more importantly, they ought to be encouraged to do so in order that the pressure is taken off the public hospital system. The government's initiative is a fantastic one. It has the overwhelming support of the Australian people and I look forward to its carriage shortly.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman, today attempted to provide a defence for what is a highly regressive measure. She tried to pretend that this measure was directed at low income earners when the facts quite clearly show that this measure is largely directed at middle and upper income earners and that there is no defence on equity grounds for this measure. Part of the $1.4 billion of taxpayers' money that will be expended in this rebate will go to those high income earners who choose to rejoin private health insurance funds, but most of it will go to those who are already insured, who are already in the system.

speech.para: This is very bad public policy. The government has not come to grips with defining the problem, which is the escalating cost of health care. They have got no solution. They made an election promise to throw money at the problem. They threw money at the problem last year. It did not work. They are now going to throw a larger bucket of money—$1.4 billion—at the problem.

The government clearly cannot make up their minds as to whether or not they want to support means testing of this measure. I am not clear from Dr Wooldridge's statements where he stands on the issue today. But what is clear is that the majority of this assistance will go to those who do not need it, and it will not solve the major public health issues in this country.

Only 23 per cent of families who earn $20,000 or less a year are in private health insurance. Seventy-seven per cent of families who earn $20,000 or less are not in private insurance; and they do not get anything of the $1.4 billion. They have to deal with the fact that the government pulls money out of public hospitals to pay a private health insurance subsidy to people who are better off. So, first of all, the government is not helping people on low incomes, because most of them do not have private health insurance.

But 72 per cent of people who earn $70,000 or more are in private health insurance and they will get the subsidies; all taxpayers will help pay their private health insurance rebates. I do not think that is equitable. It is highly regressive. It is not fair and it is not good public policy.

Twenty-five per cent of all those currently insured earn $70,000 or more. They will be getting the lion's share of the public funds that go to subsidise this measure. The government's own recent report said that the likelihood of having health insurance increased markedly as income increased. There is no defence for the proposed rebate on equity grounds.

Seventy-seven per cent of those with income under $20,000 are not insured. They get no help. They have to deal with a public health system in crisis that is not getting enough funds. But it is worse than that because the government is going to subsidise ancillary cover for the high income earners as well. The more you spend on health insurance, the more subsidy the government is going to pay you. Only 16½ per cent of those earning under $20,000 have ancillary cover. But of those who earn $70,000 or more, 64 per cent have got ancillary cover—the sort of cover that will give them dental care and sporting aids such as gym shoes and tennis racquets.

Again, the measure is not directed at those most in need—those on low incomes. The benefit, the majority of this $1.4 billion, goes to those on higher incomes—those who do not need the assistance. The classic example of this government's priorities is the abolition of the dental scheme. In the last budget, the government took $100 million out of the dental scheme and abolished it. The scheme had provided essential dental treatment for those who could not afford to pay—particularly old people who could not afford to get their teeth fixed. The government took $100 million out of the scheme and said, `That is just tough; that is how tight the budget is.' But with this measure the government will subsidise private insurance ancillary cover—50 per cent of which is for dental treatment. They will put over $200 million of public money into subsidising dental care for largely higher income earners.

The government cannot afford to pay for the dental care of those who cannot pay for it themselves. We cannot afford a public dental scheme so that the poor can have dental treatment but we can subsidise the ancillary cover of those on $100,000 to $200,000 a year so that they can get the best dental treatment available. We are going to pay for the dental care of the rich, while the poor will be left with bad teeth and unable to get any treatment at all.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is about time that the nonsense from the honourable senator was stopped. Madam Deputy President, I should not say this while you are in the chair but you made the same sorts of claims yesterday or the day before when you were speaking about the dental health program.
—I hope you are not reflecting on the chair.

—I have to remind honourable senators that the dental health program is a program that has been run by the states for years and years. But the state Labor governments ran their schemes so badly and those schemes were in such a state of decay that just before the 1993 election Labor had to promise a Commonwealth dental health scheme to try to assist the states to prop up their poorly administered health schemes. According to the budget papers, the money was not to continue. In fact, we stopped it only about six months earlier than would have been the case.

speech.para: To talk about abolishing the health scheme is a nonsense. When you look at the facts and the figures you will see that we have increased the provision of funding to the states by 17.6 per cent—a real increase and a record level of spending. We are providing almost $32 billion over the next five years to public hospitals through the Australian health care agreements. There is increased funding for the states to address the issue of dental care, which has always been a state responsibility. As I said, the Labor Party had to step in at a Commonwealth level and give some assistance to state Labor governments, which had let dental health care go into decay. To come in here and say that we have stopped funding is an absolute nonsense. The Labor Party offered one-off funding to try to prop up the scheme.

I want to refer to the myths that are floating around with regard to health. Jenny Macklin is off again with her Macklin myths. I have got a book full of them now. Here is another one—`Macklin's Millionaires'. Dr Wooldridge put out a press release which said:
Labor support no means-test on rebates to self-insured millionaires, but opposes a 30 per cent rebate for families on $70,000 combined income.
Labor's health spokesperson, Ms Jenny Macklin, has been running around the country claiming that the Government's 30% rebate for private health insurance will be a windfall for the wealthy.
`Macklin's Millionaires'. The press release continues:
As the Prime Minister said yesterday—
this was on 24 November, so it was 23 November—
it's almost as if Labor has created "a new species of elite Australians" called Macklin's Millionaires.

talk.start.para: —Would you care to refer to the honourable member by her correct title, please?

—No, I am referring to the name of the group of people. I have referred to Ms Jenny Macklin, but `Macklin's Millionaires' is a group of people. This has nothing to do with Ms Macklin's name in the sense that I am not going to call them `Ms Macklin's Millionaires.' If you want me to do that, I will—but, really, it is being a bit pedantic.

speech.para: On Neil Mitchell's radio program on 3AW, Ms Macklin revealed that the millionaires she is complaining about are actually families earning $70,000 a year. Mitchell asked her, `What is a high income family?' She said, `Over $70,000.'

So they have redefined `wealthy' to include dual income families with an income less than average weekly earnings. Male average weekly ordinary time earnings are $783.60 a week—an annual income of $40,747. And female average weekly earnings are $653.90 a week—an annual income of $34,080. So a dual income family where both partners can earn an average wage with combined income of $74,000 would be denied any assistance towards their private health insurance by Labor. These are the millionaires that Ms Macklin talks about.

So we are seeing Labor's former Senator Richardson saying Labor's health policy is wrong. He has been saying for years and years that if private health insurance drops below 30 per cent the system is virtually not viable. The problem is that—and Senator Crowley used to deny this when she was on this side of the chamber—when people leave private health insurance they are potential customers for the public system. More than one in every two operations, one in every three admissions and one in every four bed days are provided in the private sector. Health fund contributors pay today for six million bed days each year out of a total 22 million bed days. That is an enormous contribution by those 30 per cent of people who are contributing to private health insurance. Every privately insured patient who occupies a private hospital bed frees up a public bed for Medicare patients. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I must be missing something here, but it seems to me that when you talk about private health in this country there are a number of problems with it, the most significant of which is the gap. If a person shells out the fifty bucks or so a week for a family—
—That was the way the Labor Party let it run down.

—Senator, you can join this later, and I am sure you will. At the end of the day, if somebody paid fifty bucks per week to be privately insured and that were the end of the matter then I think private health in this country would be a lot healthier. But that is not the case at all. What happens is that when a person reports to a hospital for some medical service or other they are asked if they are privately insured—that is one of the first questions. I can tell you that most people who are privately insured take a while to answer that question, because they know what it is going to lead to. They know that unfortunately there is going to be in some instances no lid whatsoever on the charging regime that they are going to be subjected to. They know that if they are going in for a simple surgical procedure the probability is that they will be a couple of hundred bucks out of pocket, depending on what state they live in. I know that in my state if you have some simple surgical procedure and you are privately insured it will cost you a couple of hundred bucks. But if you want to get a hip replacement or if you want to get some of the other bits of medical gear that is around these days—it was not around 20 years ago, leastwise nowhere near to the same extent it is today—then you can multiply that couple of hundred dollars by 10 to 20.

speech.para: In fact, when I was a state member a fellow who had been to see the local orthopaedic surgeon came to see me. He was told, `I'm sorry, but you are not privately insured. Come back in 12 months time.' I took it up with the surgeon, who took the trouble to write to every state member of parliament, saying, `You did this wrong. You should have sent this bloke back to the doctor. The doctor could have written to me and said that he was in pain and maybe I could have looked at it a bit sooner instead of demanding the excessive charge that was going to be there.' I pointed out that it was the GP that had sent him to me, because the GP could not get through the system himself.

Unfortunately, a lot of people are very frustrated with the health of private health in this country. A lot of them are the officials involved in it, because they know that the lack of government and industry attention to this problem of the gap is what is really killing private health. That is what is doing it. How can you possibly shell out fifty bucks a week and then get a bill for $5,000 or $10,000 for a hip replacement? Let me make this crystal clear to those people who are arguing that this measure now before the Senate, this bill, this 30 per cent rebate, is going to solve all the problems. It is not. All it is going to do is transfer money, probably out of the public system, and hand it over—virtually saying to private health in this country, `It's okay. You don't have to address the issue of the gap. You don't have to address the issue of rising medical costs. All you have to do is go cap in hand to the government and they will give you a bit more tax deductibility.' That will help you too, because you are in the income bracket where it is going to make the world of difference.'

The reality is that private health in this country needs a lot of attention. Private health in this country needs some of the fundamental questions addressed. It does not need another bucket of leeches that these people are prepared to throw all over a dying patient who unfortunately is dying because of a blood loss.

talk.start.para: —Why didn't you ask about it in question time? There wasn't one question about this.

—At the end of the day, a third of this money, $500 million, would fix up public health in this country. I see Senator McGauran over there wanting to join in on it. I hope he is going to get on his feet. From the way he and his friends over there have been jumping in on this, you can see what the game really is. This is nothing more than just a tax dodge for them.

—I am afraid that Senator Faulkner has left his whole team in the lurch here today by picking up on this issue, because they really have not had very much to defend in terms of ALP policy. The ALP line in this matter absolutely amazes me. If you ask the community what they think of this issue, two-thirds of the community support a 30 per cent rebate. Let us go and listen to what one of the fading stars of the ALP, a former health minister, Graham Richardson, had to say about this. He cannot really understand why the ALP does not support this 30 per cent rebate. If we go back to why he is saying that, we see that he realised starkly what ALP policy was doing to the health system in this country.

speech.para: Because of their blind ideological adherence to things being totally public they have let the health system run down over 13 years. We had a terrific system when they took over government in 1983. It was a system that was duel in nature, and 70 per cent of Australians took out private health insurance. Under their stewardship over 13 years this was run down from 70 per cent to 30 per cent. What did Graham Richardson say about it getting to 30 per cent? He said, `The whole system would be on the verge of collapse if it ever got to 40 per cent.' It is now 30 per cent. It is one minute to midnight.

What is this government going to do about it? This government is taking the radical measures needed to fix the system. Under Labor there was no assistance to fix the system. What would have happened if it had been allowed to continue? What happens if the private health system in this country collapses? All those patients go on to the public system. And what is in the public system now? Very long waiting lists, overcrowded public hospitals and lack of choice. That is the legacy of the Labor government. You want to add to that now. By letting the private system collapse you are going to add to all those problems.

talk.start.para: —It won't collapse. It's a furphy.

—Three-quarters of this country think you are wrong and they support our policy on this. The largest group of people who take out private health insurance are not—as those on the other side say—rich. The vast majority of people in private insurance earn less than $30,000. And they support the system. They want to stay in the system. We want to encourage more people to get into the system. The way you do that is with a 30 per cent rebate.

speech.para: In the other place last week, Mr Horne, who is the re-elected member for Paterson, actually voted against 52 per cent of his constituents who are in private health insurance. Fifty-two per cent of the people in Paterson—41,000 people—have private health insurance. What did Bob Horne do? Bob Horne voted against them. People in the Hunter Valley were outraged that their local member would not only vote against their best interests but would deprive them of $750 a year rebate. So 41,000 people out there in Paterson are going to be $750 worse off next year and again the year after and again the year after because of Mr Horne's blind ideological adherence to the Labor policy of knocking down private hospitals in this country.

Our government is determined to restore the dual system to a healthy system of hospitals in this country. We are supported in that by recent research by the AMA, which believes that the turnaround in membership of the private health insurance system that will be created has been conservatively estimated by our government. Their estimate is a lot higher. They think this is the key measure. It is like restoring the old tax rebate system and that is the key to turning this whole issue around. If we restore that, the 30 per cent will grow to 35 per cent, 40 per cent and beyond and we will have a viable system again. I cannot understand why the member for Paterson, Mr Horne, and the ALP in general are voting against the best interests of the battlers in this country—the ones who earn under $30,000. They are the ones who are the main adherents to this system. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
