talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak about one of Australia's great industries, one that embodies the colourful history of Australia and some of its great characters. I am talking about the wool industry and I would like to tell the chamber tonight about a meeting that took place in the small New South Wales town of Goulburn yesterday, where 1,600 wool growers voted for a new beginning for their industry. They voted to reclaim their industry and their future.

speech.para: The debate was energetic and at times quite colourful. As you would expect, it was a good-natured debate. Farmers are almost always very polite. But there was no doubt about why the hundreds of men and women had driven thousands of kilometres from all around Australia and had gathered at Goulburn. They wanted to take part in the vote to put their industry into the 21st century. And they did, by overwhelmingly passing a motion of no confidence in the board of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, known as AWRAP. The board has now stood aside and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr Vaile) will soon make new appointments.

The wool industry today is at a crucial crossroad, and the fresh start that growers have voted for may indeed be the last chance for this great industry. The no-confidence motion resulted from a widespread view by growers that their wool tax funds had been squandered and that the board lacked the vision and the long-term strategy to be able to stem the decline in the wool market and to provide a new vision to increase demand and therefore price. Growers at the meeting repeatedly said they wanted to give agriculture minister Mark Vaile a clean sheet to begin planning for a new approach to the industry and to the development and, importantly, the promotion of wool.

A South Australian wool grower, Mr Peter Morgan, put the situation simply and quite colourfully when he said the industry had unsuccessfully tried to make a silk commercial purse from a bureaucratic sow's ear, where producers were at the wrong end of the market chain to promote wool. Wool promotion was, he argued, as much the responsibility of the manufacturer as it was of the growers.

Growers speaking in favour of the no-confidence motion claimed that AWRAP had spent too much time on promoting itself and not enough on promoting the product. They argued that there needed to be a report of the organisation's activities to determine where wool growers could improve their returns. They recognised that wool needed to be promoted more effectively.

They naturally feel frustrated that in the last 28 years $8 billion has been spent on wool promotion and yet wool is almost at one of the lowest prices of recent years and market share for wool growers is declining. They rejected the argument put by some that the no-confidence motion would reduce consumer confidence or that it would pose a financial risk to growers.

Wool growers did not come to this decision overnight. The seeds of this discontent were sown in the aftermath of the collapse of the reserve price scheme at the start of this decade and over the recent years of roller-coaster price fluctuations. So why did the growers feel such a sense of anger and frustration at this Goulburn meeting? I believe it was that frustration that led to growers decid ing that they would not even question the chairman of the board or the chief executive of AWRAP on the financial documents or the annual report presented. They came to debate the motion of no confidence and they simply wanted to get on with it.

Since the 1990s, the wool industry has been managing the reduction of a wool stockpile from 4.7 million bales and a debt of $2.7 billion. The official stockpile has now fallen to just over one million bales but there are, of course, around 850,000 more bales of wool in the woolsheds of Australia. Growers are also under increasing pressure as a result of the Asian crisis and the weakening European demand which has further pushed down wool prices. In fact, demand for wool has fallen in the past eight years from about 1,900 million kilograms a year to just over 1,500 million kilograms a year. Wool has never regained the 870c per kilo set in the dying days of the reserve price scheme and, as we all know, in recent weeks it has fallen to below 500c a kilo.

So where to now for the industry? It seems that new arrangements for the industry must contain at least three important principles. Firstly, there must be a performance audit of the board's activities to ensure that growers can see where Woolmark has succeeded, and where it has failed, and how growers have benefited from the research and development in dollar terms.

Secondly, the change process must be managed effectively. There must be a truly independent task force at arm's length from the retiring board. The chair must be clearly committed to change in the industry structure and culture, with a team comprising a careful mix of those with a knowledge of business and, of course, the wool industry itself. Thirdly, and most importantly, the process must be customer focused; business like in its approach, with clear and concise links between producer and customer; and with grower controls of levies and contestability of funding.

The minister for agriculture has undertaken to appoint a new chairman for AWRAP within 30 days and to establish a future directions task force for the wool industry. I am optimistic that wool growers can move forward with renewed confidence that there will be increased grower participation in the future decisions taken by the new AWRAP board and its industry activities. The aim will be to build on and sustain wool demand and to improve wool grower productivity. These are key challenges that the industry faces and they will ensure a long-term and more profitable future for the industry.

Yesterday's vote was a milestone in the democratic processes of the wool industry. For me it was a historic day and I am sure it also was for those hundreds of families who travelled from all around Australia to attend the Goulburn meeting. I was honoured to attend that meeting and to be part of the proceedings. Growers, in taking responsibility for their industry's future directions and for its reform, have made a courageous decision to look boldly to the future of one of Australia's most important agricultural industries, one which embodies some of our nation's greatest characters.

talk.start.para: —One of the greatest ironies of the recent election was that, whilst economic commentators lamented the lack of scope in the tax debate, crucial elements of Labor's tax package were completely under-analysed. The status attributed to the GST was singular: reform equals GST. This had the effect of constraining the tax debate into one of pro or anti the coalition's new tax.

speech.para: It is an indictment of those who offered their active advocacy to the GST that a little peek around the millennial corner was not taken. This simple voyeuristic endeavour would have brought into sharp relief the inevitable damage that a GST will do to the Australian economy. Quite simply, if a GST makes some goods dearer, it is bound to encourage Australians to buy via global e-commerce. Electronic commerce, the practical facilitator of a globalised economy, will inevitably reduce the revenue raising capability of a GST. Global access to markets via the Internet, to electronic services and to intangible or digitised property will defy national borders, and hence tax laws pertaining to consumption, relegating the GST as a tax for times past.

Labor's tax proposals, which offered an innovative approach to leveraging social outcomes from the income tax system, remain a worthy alternative base from which to build a tax regime for the next century. Conversely, any proposal that perpetuates or enhances inequity, like the coalition's GST, will inevitably break down social cohesion.

The OECD Ministerial Forum on Electronic Commerce held in Ottawa in early October represented an important forum for discussions on these issues to progress. Unfortunately for Australia, we did not have a minister present. Whilst I acknowledge this had more to do with the timing of the federal election, it was nonetheless an indictment that none of the state Liberal ministers could find time in their schedules to attend. Had a minister attended, he could have brought back the bad news for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. The bad news for the government is that electronic commerce will undermine a GST within a relatively short space of time.

Instead of looking forward and anticipating the challenges of a globalised economy, the GST, as I said, is a tax for times past. It is a tax based on the assumption of an isolated fiscal regime, where revenue collection can be structurally linked to domestic consumption within national parameters. With the Internet as the medium and electronic commerce as the mechanism for economic globalisation, this assumption is false. To base our tax system on a false assumption is both foolish and irresponsible.

The Ottawa ministerial forum made many recommendations as well as articulating many of the unresolved challenges e-commerce will bring to member nations. The report entitled Electronic Commerce: Taxation Framework Conditions, produced by the Committee on Fiscal Affairs, outlines the principles that have given Australia and other OECD members policy guidance to date. The central tenet is that the tax regime of member nations should not discriminate between the digital or physical commerce environment.

Australia has embraced this principle. Only today we saw the Prime Minister make a joint statement with respect to a theoretical bilateral agreement, when what we saw in fact was an echoing of many of the outcomes that were articulated two months ago at the OECD ministerial forum. There are many other features of this statement that are contextualised by a rhetorical commitment, stated in the report as `the potential' of electronic commerce `to be one of the great economic developments of the 21st century'. How Australia extracts the potential value of this great economic development will not be governed by our internal fiscal regime but rather by how we leverage ourselves in the global marketplace. Australia is a comparably small economy, so great care needs to be taken to ensure that our future economic base is nurtured. That is why the Prime Minister's failure to confront the GST in today's joint statement is so irresponsible.

The Ottawa ministerial forum traversed many issues, not least being the impact and effect of electronic commerce on a nation's ability to tax consumption. The report Electronic Commerce: Taxation Framework Conditions identifies four elements of an electronic commerce taxation framework specifically relating to consumption tax. Firstly, rules for the consumption taxation of cross-border trade should result in the jurisdiction where consumption takes place and an international consensus should be sought on the circumstances under which supplies are held to be consumed in a jurisdiction. Secondly, for the purposes of consumption taxes, the supply of digitised products should not be treated as a supply of goods.

Thirdly, where business and other organisations within a country acquire services and intangible property from suppliers outside the country, countries should examine the use of reverse charge, self-assessment or other equivalent mechanisms where this would give immediate protection of their revenue base and of the competitiveness of domestic suppliers. Fourthly, countries should ensure that appropriate systems are developed in cooperation with the WCO and in consultations with carriers and other interested parties to collect tax on the importation of physical goods and that such systems do not impede revenue collection and the efficient delivery of products to consumers.

So, as you can see, the OECD report poses some fascinating riddles with each of these points highlighting the complexity that a consumption tax introduces to the electronic commerce challenge. At this stage, the OECD have been unable to offer any better advice than self-regulation for the taxing of services or intangible or digital property purchased via the Internet. It would be an envied administration that could extract tax voluntarily, so this concept is not going to be realised.

The implications of this weakness of the GST in a globalised economy must not be underestimated. Claims that the current small proportion of e-commerce sales in the crucial business to private consumer category justify a steady as you go approach look forlorn in the context of the phenomenal growth that Australia is experiencing in Internet connectivity, with a 46 per cent growth in Internet connectivity to households in the last nine months alone and a subsequent growth in e-commerce predicted as security solutions are refined and commercialised.

The Internet and television will collide in an amazing kaleidoscope of interactive entertainment and information services in lounge rooms around Australia. A global smorgasbord through which goods and services can be purchased will become available and consumers will no longer be confined to a domestic marketplace. This new media will be driven, as is conventional media, by advertising revenues. When the market is a global one and seeing an ad from a US based travel agent and booking online may provide a better product for a cheaper price for consumers, not to mention avoiding the national GST, the dangers become clear.

If a GST makes some goods dearer, it is a reasonable assumption that it will encourage Australians to buy via global e-commerce, thus avoiding tax and potentially wounding Australian industry. Where are the Australian Taxation Office plans to stop this seepage? If the current e-commerce threat to the tax base is a worry, the GST will accelerate it. With the Internet identified as a priority for the tax department, you would think the tax commis sioner would have had more to say. The government has been deathly silent on the implications of the GST with respect to e-commerce. It is about time that they released the study and recommendations arising from that.

All in all, these issues point to one outcome, and one outcome only: the irrelevance and the lack of suitability which the GST represents to Australia in the 21st century. The silence of the government, particularly in the context of today's statement, certainly shows, firstly, that they either have looked at these issues, realised the serious implications and are choosing not to say anything or, secondly—something which is almost a worse scenario—that they do not understand. Time will tell the outcome of this issue, but in the meantime the government has an obligation to confront these issues actively and put their intentions and plans before the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —Tonight, Australia received some very important news from the World Heritage Committee meeting in Kyoto. It declared that the construction of the Jabiluka uranium mine within Kakadu should be halted. As the Senate will know, the commission agreed to consider again the question of inscribing the Kakadu world heritage site on the List of World Heritage in Danger until April next year, allowing time for a further three reports to be prepared and considered.

speech.para: The last couple of weeks have seen the Australian government taking frantic and desperate measures to turn the World Heritage Committee around. Australian bureaucrats were suggesting as late as yesterday that the Australian government had no constitutional powers to stop the mine. I want to remind the Minister for the Environment and Heritage tonight of three practical steps he could take to do that. He could warn ERA that if they proceed they do so at their own financial risk. I would have thought that the government would have been wanting to minimise any sort of compensation claim that taxpayers might have to meet. This would certainly be one very responsible way of doing that.

The minister could issue a proclamation under the World Heritage Properties Act. That is, as I understand it, what that legislation is for. A proclamation could be made and given assent by the Governor-General within 24 hours, after which time the minister can then issue a determination and the Northern Territory and the mining company would be obliged to act on that determination.

The minister has been saying that he would not actually allow the mining of uranium before April. But as we all know, the program would not have allowed mining before then in any case. What the minister has failed to acknowledge is that construction of the mine is in itself a significant factor in putting at risk those natural and cultural world heritage values identified by the investigating team in October. The minister could indicate to ERA that he will not provide an export licence unless the company agrees to halt the mine construction now.

I think it should have been very obvious to the minister that the reprieve granted to Australia by the World Heritage Committee would not make any sense at all unless it were accompanied by that commitment to halt the mine. I would like to put on the public record tonight the reasons why to do other than require construction to be stopped would have been impossible for the committee.

I want to quote from a letter to the committee by Professor Nicholas Robinson of the Centre for Environmental Legal Studies at Pace University, New York. Professor Robinson is a specialist in international environmental law and is Chairman of the Commission on Environmental Law of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. He stresses that his opinion is based on established legal procedures, not on any political issues associated with Jabiluka. He says:

. . . I am concerned that the recommendation of the World Heritage Bureau that Kakadu not be listed as endangered, despite a finding that the site is in fact endangered, would violate the basic procedures laid down under the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

The Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention clearly indicate that once the committee has before it sufficient evidence to satisfy itself that there is "serious and specific danger", . . . then the Committee, under paragraph 85, is obliged to inscribe the property on the List of World Heritage in Danger, with the "program of corrective measures" proposed to be immediately implemented by the State Party—
that is, Australia—
concerned.

The Mission report [on Kakadu] recommended that Kakadu be inscribed on the List of World Heritage in Danger. It found "serious and specific dangers" pursuant to Article 11(4) of the Convention and that at least one of the Guidelines criteria was proven. These findings included scientific, aesthetic and cultural concerns. The Bureau has accepted the report as "both thorough and credible".

Professor Robinson points to the six months delay before reconsideration to allow further reports of its `efforts to prevent further damage and mitigate all the threats identified in the UNESCO mission report'. He argues that it is questionable under the guidelines that this is possible and argues that, under the circumstances whereby the mine is proceeding, not only can there be no efforts to prevent further damage, but also the serious and specific danger may well be exacerbated unless mining construction ceases and corrective measures are implemented as determined by the committee. He says:

Were there to be an immediate suspension of all construction of the mining operations that endanger the property, pending such studies, then the delay in listing might be consistent with the World Heritage Convention.

However, since the mining operations have been found to be the cause of the endangerment, further study activities alone do not appear to constitute "corrective action" . . . and nor do they abate the threats identified by the Mission report.

Professor Robinson draws attention to the interpretation of the World Heritage Convention and the guidelines which is reinforced by application of the precautionary principle under international law, restated in principle 15 of the Rio de Janeiro Declaration on Environment and Development which states:

In order to protect the environment, the precautionary approach shall be widely applied by States according to their capabilities. Where there are threats of serious or irreversible damage, lack of full scientific certainty shall not be used as a reason for postponing cost-effective measures to prevent environmental degradation.
Australia is obliged, in article 4 of the World Heritage Convention to—and I quote again:

. . . identify, protect, conserve, present and transmit to future generations, the properties of world heritage. Not to list a site that has been found to be in danger would violate the Precautionary principle.

I would have thought that it would have been bleedingly obvious to the government that the mine construction should stop immediately this became a matter of consideration by the World Heritage Committee. It certainly was obvious to the Democrats, and that is what we argued. Professor Robinson goes on to talk about the cultural values of Kakadu. He said:

There is a further reason for the World Heritage Committee to ensure that the procedural guidelines are closely adhered to. The cultural landscape of the Kakadu National Park, as a world heritage site, is defined in part by the indigenous people of the region. A basic consideration of all Human Rights issues is that the established legal process always be closely adhered to, and not adapted expediently in order to meet perceived exigencies of the moment. The Rio de Janeiro Declaration on Environment and Development in Principle 22, emphasises the importance of respecting indigenous people and their communities, and that "States should recognise and duly support their identity, culture and interests, and enable their effective participation in the achievement of sustainable development".

Cultural tourism is important to the World Heritage Convention and to the sustainable use of cultural sites; thus there are economic interests relevant here. More important, however, is the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which guarantees to everyone the rights inter alia, in Article 21 to participate in government decisions affecting them, in Article 27 to the legal protection of cultural heritage, and above all in Article 7 to equal protection before the law.

A decision to change the rules of the game in mid-course would leave the World Heritage Committee open to the appearance of disregarding fundamental human rights of the indigenous people identified in the Mission report.

Today we saw the minister during question time take a dorothy dixer in which he thumbed his nose at the World Heritage Committee in terms of cultural values, and he actually suggested that the indigenous people affected by this uranium mine in their midst stood to benefit by its go-ahead. The argument goes along the lines that Aboriginal people have enjoyed the benefits of the royalties from Ranger and they want more of the same.

I have actually been up to the township of Jabiru, which serves the Ranger mine. I called in to the health centre there and talked to the director. I asked her what was the most serious health problem in the area. The answer came back that it was scabies and that 90 per cent of Aboriginal children in this area were affected by this Third World disease. Scabies has very serious implications in the medium and long term for the major organs of the body. Life expectancy in this area is low, even by Aboriginal standards. So if these are indicators of affluence, then it is new to me.

The $48 million in royalties over 18 years from Ranger have not gone to make the traditional owners in this area rich. In fact they have been used by the land council for the most basic services—services which non-indigenous Australians take for granted. They have also been used to develop tourism ventures. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak this evening I note the occurrence of World AIDS Day 1998, World AIDS Day having commenced in 1988. The timely theme for World AIDS Day 1998 is entitled `Force for Change: World AIDS campaign with young people'. The devastation of the AIDS pandemic is only too evident and not one that I should need to draw to the attention of senators. In December last year UNAIDS and the World Health Organisation released extraordinary figures that showed there is about one-third more people living with HIV than estimated in December 1996. The figures in fact estimate that there are a staggering 16,000 new infections each day, which has added 5.8 million infections to the 1997 total. It is now estimated that there are over 30 million people living with HIV infection. Of these 30 million people, at least one-third are young people aged between 10 and 24 years.

speech.para: The World AIDS Day 1998 home page on the Internet points out that in the, say, one minute that I have been speaking, five young people world wide between the ages of 10 and 24 years have been infected with HIV. The home page goes on to say:
In the absence of a vaccine or a cure, education is the only weapon available to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS.

Educating young people is central to our fight to reduce the incidence of HIV-AIDS. This year's slogan, `A force for change,' well reflects what all community leaders and indeed all Australians need to actively pursue—that is, changing attitudes, particularly those in relation to discrimination against those with HIV, and to gay issues, through education.

Australia's elected representatives have an opportunity to lead that force for change. It is not acceptable to pretend that the pandemic sweeping our planet is in fact somebody else's responsibility. We should be 100 per cent behind any force for change. Education of young people, the greatest resource in our nation, is pivotal in this endeavour. Young people should understand both the myths and the realities of HIV infection and AIDS. We should ensure that we lead the way with tolerance and understanding of the issues, and we must provide support for people living with HIV infection. That is the only way that we can in fact be any sort of a force for change—by educating the community.

It is also important that as community leaders we acknowledge that HIV is an issue of concern which does not confine itself to the gay community. Indeed, across much of the world the dominant method of the transferral of HIV-AIDS is in fact high-risk heterosexual contact. In sub-Saharan Africa, South-East Asia, Latin America, the Caribbean and North America the primary means of transferral is in fact via heterosexual sex. The stories that emerge from these regions about the nature of infection are startling. The UNAIDS global summary of the HIV-AIDS epidemic contains references, for example, to towns on the South African borders where seven pregnant women in 10 tested HIV positive in 1995. Clearly, many of those from these regions are infected because of a lack of education about practices and behaviour which would protect against infection. Just as education is a crucial issue in these regions, so it is in Australia.

The government has made a solid commitment to education on issues surrounding HIV-AIDS. Earlier this month I had the opportunity to launch an HIV-AIDS Resource Manual on behalf of the Minister for Health and Aged Care, my colleague the Hon. Michael Wooldridge MP. The manual is a comprehensive, 300-page, cross-referenced resource that contains detailed information for HIV educators and service providers. It covers the latest developments in treatments, education, prevention, sexual health and other topics. It is an affirmation of the government's support for and commitment to the reduction of HIV infection in this country. That commitment is not just for the implementation of education campaigns; it also supports the development of an effective and skilled work force that operates in partnership with the government, the medical profession and others for whom the HIV-AIDS Resource Manual will be an invaluable guide.

The government has demonstrated its commitment to the reduction of HIV infection by actively pursuing community participation. The government acts in partnership with organisations such as the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations and AIDS and related diseases councils throughout Australia. Recently, the AIDS Council of New South Wales opened relatively new premises in Parramatta, my own base, to better support the community of western Sydney and those living with HIV. I am a strong supporter of ACON Western Sydney and will be taking a constructive role in its future.

Part of the government's active partnership in reducing HIV infection comes from our support of these organisations in the development and implementation of national education and prevention initiatives, particularly those that target gay men in Australia. Senators are no doubt aware that Australia is recognised world wide for our success in addressing the HIV-AIDS pandemic, and in particular for the bipartisan political approach that has been taken over so many years. Innovative education programs have been an important part of that success. The govern ment continues to support the need for ongoing education and is committed to the development of a fourth national HIV-AIDS strategy.

Recently the minister and the government supported a national review of gay men's education in Australia and the development of a national education strategy. The review confirmed the success to date of education programs in Australia in controlling and reducing the spread of HIV. The government response to the education strategy was developed jointly with the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations. One initiative coming out of that response is the development of a national training agenda for educators in the area.

The Commonwealth is bringing together key stakeholders to set priorities for a range of national training initiatives, which will support educators in their work of minimising infection. The Commonwealth has also brought together a national consensus group to oversight the development of a national evaluation framework for HIV-AIDS health promotion programs. AFAO and AIDS councils are members of the committees oversighting both projects.

Another remarkable achievement this year in taking Australia to the forefront in reducing the rate of HIV infection was, in my view, the election of my colleague the minister, Michael Wooldridge, to the position of Chair of the Programme Coordinating Board of the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS. Dr Wooldridge said on this occasion:

This is obviously a personal honour but more importantly recognition of Australia's leadership in research, treatment, the development of pragmatic responses to HIV/AIDS and the success that our community has had in having these issues addressed in an understanding and non-judgemental manner. Australia now has further opportunity to play its part in the concerted international efforts, under the auspices of UNAIDS, to slow the spread of HIV.

Minister Wooldridge's election to this important international position can only further strengthen Australia's leading role in combating the spread of HIV in Australia but, more importantly, within our region and around the world.

In work away from the parliament, in taking any sort of role in consolidating as a force for change—to adopt this year's theme for World AIDS Day—it is useful to recall the words of Peter Piot, the Executive Director of UNAIDS, in his plenary speech to the 4th International Congress on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific in October last year. He said:

The arrival of AIDS puts every society under strain. It searches out our weaknesses, throws harsh light on hidden areas, and demands that we discuss subjects whose very existence we would prefer to ignore or deny. The societies of Asia and the Pacific are no exception. Traditions may be different, values may be different, but the disease is the same. It is just as ruthless, just as relentless, and just as eager to exploit hypocrisy and ignorance. We as human beings have little choice but to admit our weaknesses and build on our strengths. And in the face of an external threat one of our most powerful capabilities is community action. But if communities are to take responsibility for their own defence they need the freedom to do so. To isolate people living with HIV or AIDS is to weaken them and reduce their ability to help themselves. Similarly, to marginalise drug users, or sex workers, or the gay community, or anyone else living outside the mainstream of national life, is to undermine their ability to organise and protect themselves against AIDS.

We should heed Peter Piot's words. To be a force for change, we have to educate the community against prejudice. In this rapidly changing world, we must ensure that young people have access to all the information available on HIV, so that together we can reduce the incidence of HIV infection and offer all people living with HIV both commitment and support.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 12 November 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Coalition's election promise to legislate for consumer benefits arising from open competition in telecommunications, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will seek passage of legislation providing for the strengthening of competition, prior to the introduction of any further Telstra sale bills and, if so, will those competition reforms include an obligation for Telstra to: (a) disclose its basic network and service costs to competitors when it negotiates access to its network and services; and (b) file all of its intra-industry agreements with competitors with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, so that Telstra is not able to deny consumers the benefits of genuine competition and lower prices.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1998, which is part of the package of telecommunications legislation the Government introduced into the Parliament on 12 November 1998, includes several amendments to strengthen competition and these amendments will take affect prior to the further privatisation of Telstra.

Specifically, the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill includes provisions to enable Telstra (and any other carrier) to be required to disclose its basic network and service costs to competitors so they can be used in negotiations for access to its network and services. Under Division 6 of Part XIB of the Trade Practices Act 1974 the

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is able to make rules requiring one or more specified carriers or carriage service providers to keep and retain records. These records, may, amongst other things, relate to a firm's network and service costs. Proposed items 6 to 25, 27 and 28 of Schedule 1 to the Bill enable the ACCC to require a carrier or carriage service provider to prepare reports containing information kept under record keeping rules and enable the ACCC to disclose or require the disclosure of those all or part of those reports. These provisions will therefore enable Telstra's competitors to be provided with information, where appropriate, on Telstra's costs for use in their access negotiations.

The ACCC has been working with industry to develop new record-keeping rules for accounting separation, which amongst other things, will identify Telstra's costs. The ACCC has recently selected Arthur Anderson to finalise these rules for implementation by carriers. Carriers are expected to implement the rules in 1999.
The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill does not include provisions requiring Telstra to file all of its intra-industry agreements with competitors with the ACCC.

However, under Divisions 4 and 5 of Part XIB of the Trade Practices Act, the ACCC already has discretionary powers which enable it to require Telstra to file various charges, including charges as would be set out in intra-industry access agreements. The ACCC may also provide public access to filed charges if it is satisfied the public interest benefit would outweigh both the public detriment through any lessening of competition and any substantial prejudice to the commercial interest of the person resulting from disclosure of the information.
